Where satisfying paths cross ants discover more efficient paths.  As food is taken it's value decreases... at 0 the food is gone.  The more satisfied ants that arrive at the colony, the more ants are created/dispatched.  Thus colonies search using relatively little aggregate energy and then harvest using high aggregate energy,  When an ant follows the expectation of a satisfaction scent and it goes cold (food depleted or moved), it extends by random wander till it is low on energy and then follows the home scent gradient back (Sometimes wandering across stronger more efficient paths )  This allows the efficient exhaustion of localised clusters of food and food that is 'moved' (being their God, I sometimes mess with them)  On not finding food a 'disappointment' scent is dropped. There are still enough ants at the depleted site to random-wander the wider area where the food source was before returning. We remember the feeling and that we have known it, but we don't remember what it is.   But this is not proof that not enough neurons were mysteriously working in the background to maintain the ant-brain. It's becoming aware of how flimsy what we truly know is, to the point where forming really clever thought can be quickly wasted - if we didn't have really, really good memories -- at least compared to other beings on the planet.  An example: the most clever birds will have memories of where they've been, and even recognize people. I have a magpie that keeps coming back to my house, even though we stopped feeding them over a year ago. It comes back and waits for us, and then has a reaction of some sort when it sees us. I don't think it knows why, or can reflect on it. But that there is a memory and a reaction that isn't just mechanically triggered by a section in the brain delegated to "emotion", that I'm completely certain of.  People act in the same way. And if we couldn't speak, but just squawked a lot instead(completely impossible to imagine..), I'm sure we would have a very hard time convincing anyone else, human or not, that there was a difference between instinctive bonds and evolutionary psychological traits - and what we would like to do and what we are interested in, what we want, etc.  Nevertheless, intelligent thought is not built on individual mechanical functions of neurons being triggered by mechanical causes. If so, we would know, for a fact, what we were going to think, what we would do, and what we are going to attempt. And at least, even with very crude measurement systems (or just writing down what we think), we would be able to predict very easily how people would think to answer certain questions, how they would go about reflecting on certain things, how they would solve simple problems, etc.   But we can't do that. In fact, we can't do that with pretty stupid animals, either (outside very specific tests, where humans would be equally predictable).   So the thought here is that yes, it's the same physical type of neurons, that perform the same type of task. But thought, what I'm describing as thought here, at least, does not occur mechanically as a result.  So it's probably possible to form thought and reason through certain things in small brains, in birds, pets, etc. And it's perhaps similar to what we're doing, remembering long reams of seeming nonsense, that we can then adjust and reason ourselves around. But this kind of thought is not a result of the individually mechanical functions becoming sufficiently complex.  So it's emergent from the system existing. But it's not a given that very sophisticated individually mechanical functions will result in that kind of thought I'm describing. In fact, I sincerely don't think that you need to be particularly "advanced" or complex to have that kind of thought to begin with.  What I mean by that is that if you designed AI that could appear to reflect and adjust it's "thought process", this would very quickly become awfully human-like(although we don't want to design robots that linger outside your window, because they are wondering what is luring them back. But individually sophisticated networks of individual routines - no matter how complex, no matter how intertwined and relative to the next step it would be - will not end up having even the appearance of intelligent thought. It will have the appearance of a sophisticated routine. And that will always be the full extent of it. Sapolsky also conflates linearity, sensitivity to initial conditions (chaotic), and time-reversibility.  He claims that the three are equivalent when in fact there are evolution functions for every yes/no combination of those three properties (except that there are no linear chaotic maps).    Some examples:  time-irreversible but linear and non-chaotic: y[n+1] = 1  time-reversible and non-chaotic but non-linear: y[n+1] = y[n] ^ 2  What are the true relationships between complexity and the properties he mentions?  Far from all three being equivalent, the only general relationship I can think of is that noninearity is a necessary condition for chaos.   Additionally, these two lectures complete misrepresent how reductionist science deals with uncertainty.  Variations in data are not simply considered "measurement error".  Almost all modern scientists use Bayesian inference to reason under uncertainty.  Models are built around our lack of knowledge about the physical systems they represent, including measurement errors and unknown details.  To use body temperature as an example, a reductionist model need not attribute temperature variations to lack of thermometer quality.  Instead, the variations are expected because our model considers "body temperature" to be a probability distribution with expectation equal to 98.6, but with a variance on the order of 1-2 degrees (so 99.6 would not be impossible).    That being said, chaotic behavior is a huge problem for Bayesian inference. When probability mass is spread around in unpredictable and analytically unassailable ways, our simple probabilistic models fail.  However, that does not mean that reductionist approaches are doomed.  We can empirically build models of the chaotic behavior itself!  We represent our lack of knowledge about the future evolution of a system using time evolution functions that spread probability mass around an attractor.  This is done explicitly and implicitly across all branches of science.

With regard to the idea of the necessity of centralization for such data collection, which we both rightly regard with some trepidation, I think there is an alternative, one that has "emerged" from the internet itself.  I'm not a computer guy, but I think they call it "cloud" processing/cloud storage/cloud development.  That could be the wrong word, but the idea is that of decentralization of processing/storage/development of software.    In the old day of Naptster, we used to steal music, but the software was hosted on the Napster servers and, after a legal battle, the government shut it down.  That model was subsequently replaced by non-centralized alternatives, like the .torrent file sharing platform, and I think others, which allow files and the software to share those files to be hosted independently on millions of computers all talking to each other in a vast web.  To shut it down, any agency would have to prosecute all the millions of individual users separately, and that would not be cost-effective.  At least that's the idea.  So that's sort of  a decentralized cloud-storage/hosting.    A more upstanding side of this emergent phenomenon(not involving intellectual property theft), you can download a small program to host other sub-apps to allow scientific projects that require heavy processing to  utilize your computer processor when you're not using it, and automatically re-upload the processed data to the scientists.  This allows the scientists to perform such research without having to buy millions of dollars worth the computers.  They outsource the processing to charities, which are us, and it costs us nothing, in theory.  So I think of that as cloud-processing.  There is some centralization there: there is a scientists somewhere to whom all the data is eventually sent, but the processing is dispersed.   The Linux operating system what I think of as an example of "cloud-development."  The original software was put out on the web, the whole code visible and available to everyone.  Everyone was allowed to modify it at will, so people kept improving it and putting it back out there.  People kept improvements they liked, disregarded code they didn't like, and more popular modifications became permanent in a kind of democratic 'survival of the fittest' code race, leading to the software's evolution.  Very much like biological evolution, which also was decentralized, unless one adopts a creationist view. (I'm still open to the idea of genetic tampering by aliens from outer space.)    So, those are just some loose seed concepts to which one might turn for a decentralized collection and processing of data by a program designed to estimate average human will.  It's worth noting, by the way, that such a program could be designed to constantly calibrate itself by testing itself with real-world predictions that can be verified by other means.  Predicting the stock markets or elections, for example, and then watching to see to what degree the predictions are correct.  The software would be tweaked over and over to get the predictions more and more accurate.  Effectively, it would be "learning" to take more and more factors into account as the human programmers(humanity itself) learn more about ourselves.   As we are not omnipotent, there would always be a margin of error.  But that's nothing new.  The question is whether we could shrink that margin down from current methods.  The benefit though would be not just from shrinking the margin of error but from an massive increase in cost efficiency in terms of real dollars and human effort.    Let me be frank; my personal intuition and assumption would be that such software could never work.  I only mentioned the idea in the context of Saplosky's lecture because I have heard stories that in fact similar software does work, contrary to my own intuition.  That it is used to predict fashion trends(which effect markets) and terrorist attacks.  If that is true and it works, it could be used for a a much wider array of purposes, including elections, by averaging the public will, thereby eliminating, in theory, the need for public representatives, allowing us to drastically upgrade democracy.   To put it succinctly, with regard to politics, such software could, in theory, allow us to:  use  the pre-existing dispersed computers of humanity to process the vast data of complexity in order to bring the accuracy of small scale tribal democracies to large democracies without the need for representative intermediaries.   When one follows this up, there are some really interesting thoughts that begin to emerge.  For example:  Person A, might vote Yes on some referendum, and person B might vote No.  But does that really mean the average will of the two of them is 50/50?  Consider that person A might feel very, very strongly on the issue, whereas person B might be ambivalent but only slightly leaning towards No.  The current voter system makes no distinction between strong feeling and relatively ambivalent disinterest.  That's not how we run our private lives.  If I have two children and one prefers ice cream with peanuts, but the other will gag and die if he eats peanuts, I'm getting the ice cream without peanuts.  Software that averages human will by collecting internet data, such as the frequency of certain words/phrases, numbers of articles and blog posts containing such phrases etc, would be, by default, weighting more heavily the desire of the person whose desire is stronger, if we assume that such a person will put their ideas out there more, effectively "campaigning" for their viewpoint.   Red flags should go up, however.  Do we really want that?  Is that really fair?  Should a person's vote count more if they care more?  And can we accurately assess strength of caring by such means?  Certainly not for individuals, but can we for societal average even, assuming margins of error on both sides will cancel each other out?    If we don't want that, the software could, in theory, be made to assign all data from a given individual to that individual and count that as one vote, rather than counting each word/phrase/article separately.  That would, however, require the end of anonymity on the internet, which I don't want.    Keep in mind, I really have only the barest notion of how such programs might work from watching some news program on it; I may have mischaracterized.    Having made that caveat, one can see that such an endeavor becomes ethically as well as technically complicated, as all revolutions are.  I don't even know for certain if I'd be in favor of it.  There would definitely be potential for such technology to be subverted for use in Orwellian schemes.  That threat should loom heavy in the mind, behind everything I'm suggesting.  In truth the clever find ways to subvert every system to serve their ends.  The self-interest of the clever has been winning the struggle for control of humanity at least since the invention of religion.    The problem with disregarding such potential is this:  If such software is possible, and the idea is out there, it will be used.  If not be us, for democracy, then by whom, and to what end?  Once technology enables a new capability, the old way of doing things ceases to remain feasible, even if it was better, which, in this case is dubious.  The biological analogy is that when the environment changes, the species must adapt; being fit for the previous environment is not longer sufficient.  We can not stop the world from changing; we can only try to assert our interests in the ever-evolving paradigm, inserting them into that web of complexity that is reality, in hopes of a preferable emergence.
